captions.text:
[SOUND] So how did scrawny Steve Rogers
turned into super human Captain America?

A lot of people don't know, but what it
comes

down to is that super soldier serum and
vita ray process.
What's inside the super soldiers serum, I

don't know the scientist in Marvel's
universe don't

know but it's a lot of fun to speculate
what could have been inside of that.
What we do know is that we know a lot of

the genes that are involved with let's say
peak physical human shape.

This means we understand the genes that
increase muscle mass we

know about the genes that increase oxygen
carrying load within your blood.

We know a lot of this information and we
actually have a lot of tools

to specifically manipulate those
individual genes in order
to turn them on and turn them off.

We actually call that full term epigenetic
modification, so basically

a light switch that you can put onto a
specific gene.

And more importantly, we have a lot of
tools that take advantage of that.
We have a lot of genome editing tools,

things like Zinc finger nucleases Cas9
CRISPR systems.
The fact is is that these tools are there,

we can use them, and we can specifically
target individual

genes within your genome, epigenetically
modify them, turn on a

gene, turn it off, and hope that those
specific genes,

in this case, can basically seek out
specific genes that

are, let's say, related to making your
muscle really really

large, or making you very strategically
minded, or making you

incredibly fast, increasing your stamina,
but that isn't enough, right?

So, I don't know if you guys remember, in
the movie, there was this

use of vita rays, and it is important in
the comic books as well.

[NOISE] So, the inject him, they wait, and
then they put him

inside the cita chamber, where they just
zap him with these lights.
These lights of mysterious origins and

powers, but what is really interesting
about

that, is that it ties into a lot of really
interesting approaches to pharmacotherapy.

There are a lot of photo sensitive
carriers of drugs

that exist in development that, that are
being researched right now.

One example are dendrimers for example or
if you

shoot UV light at them, they actually
break up.

So anything they're carrying gets released
into

the tissue that they are currently
embedded in.
So if you imagine Steven Rogers with

one of these nano carriers carrying
everything he

needs, let's say genome editing tools to
turn

on the right genes for increase muscle
mass.

You put it in him, you put it in your
muscle, and

then you zap him with these vita rays or
UV light or

anything like that, you can specifically
activate these molecules to release their

load and to have a very specific function
and a very specific tissue.

Which isn't to say at all, I maybe should
try

this at home, in fact, it's probably a
very bad

idea and the extent to which we've
explored these directions

have been mostly in lab mice and things
like that.

Either way, you know, it's fun to
speculate these things

and that's why we have comic books, movies
and science fiction.
[MUSIC].
For more please visit us at Standford.edu

title: Stanford researcher explains the science behind Captain America

comments.text:
So enemies just have to zap Capt. with lightshizzle and he will be weak 
again...?﻿
comments.author: Steeeveeeeeeeeeee

comments.text:
+Steeeveeeeeeeeeee Why wouldn't they? Medicines are given in very precise 
doses, and they would break down in the light.
Even if they weren't dissolved, the same chemicals again wouldn't cause a 
reverse process. 

Now, if the bad guys shot him with darts carrying some sort of anti-serum, 
however...
comments.author: True Velox

comments.text: Why would they dissolve completely? Lol.
comments.author: Steeeveeeeeeeeeee

comments.text:
Since the gene-alternating chemicals would already have been activated and 
dissolved, no. The light simply activates the injected serum, it doesn't 
affect Steve himself.
comments.author: True Velox

comments.text:
Given the amount of things that went from science-fiction to science-fact 
it's quite possible that in the future scientists will develop these tools 
to such an extent that they will be a part of human daily life.﻿
